Key Arguments: The bill disregards the fundamental right to freedom of speech.
It creates a distinction between politicians, journalists, educational institutions, and regular citizens, suppressing the voices of ordinary people.
The internet as a democratic platform is at risk due to this legislation.
Excessive fines will lead to more restrictive speech on digital services.
Determining truth is impossible as new information constantly emerges.
The bill could be used by large digital services to stifle competition and innovation.
The extraterritorial application of the bill is impractical and threatens global freedom of expression.
The bill contradicts the News Media Bargaining Code, indicating a lack of coherent policy direction.
It marginalizes minorities and restricts their ability to challenge accepted facts.
The bill creates a culture of fear among digital platform providers and users.
Delegating legislative power to private entities raises constitutional and legal issues.
Notable Quotes: This legislation creates a clear distinction between politicians, journalists, educational institutions, and regular citizens.
The internet is the most significant democratic invention in human history, providing a platform for regular individuals to have a voice.
Accurately determining what is true or untrue is an impossible task.
The proposed industry codes, heavily influenced by big players in the industry, could become 'anti-competitive wedges'.
The bill's approach marginalizes minorities and restricts their ability to challenge previously accepted facts.
